title: Is it true that 95% of the stars that will ever exist have already been born and the universe have enough gas for ONLY 5% more stars? - Quora

response.answer_text: It is not about the remaining gas, because the rate of star formation depends on more factors and is not yet fully understood. So the correct way to say it is “from its peak value 3.5 billion years after the Big Bang, the rate of stellar formation has decreased exponentially towards the value it has now, 3% of the peak. So only 5% of the known number of stars will be formed in the future, even if we wait forever”. Star Formation Sputtering Out Across the Universe

We are not advanced enough at this time to even send a human to the next closest planet that a human could have a possibility to survive on for a few hours, Mars, the rest are either too hot or not solid enough to land on, so whoever you got your info from is pathetically wrong. Earth will be gone in a few billion years and there are planets that are the size of a marble now that will be the size of earth by then. The universe is infinite as far as we know, who knows what happens a thousand or a million light years away. At the fastest speed we can travel now, it would take 125,000 years to get to proxima centauri, the next closest solar system. Biological being like us will never last long enough, we will have to be able to transfer our being to a mechanical computer device to achieve that.
